destination.label: Delhi
destination.title: New Delhi: the scent of India

content.intro:
New Delhi, the capital of India with a history that goes back to the Mahabharata, is a richly diverse melting pot of cultures, flavours and aromas that thrills the heart of travellers.

Delhi, the seat of power for more than a thousand years, has seen the dynasties of the Lodi, the Mughals, and later, that of the British Raj, rise and fall. In 1914, English architect Edwin Lutyens' mission was to build New Delhi. Through various buildings, such as the palace of the residence of the Viceroy of India and Rashtrapati Bhavan, the official residence of the President, the power of the empire of British settlers was reflected, especially through the use of stone. The project was completed in 1931, and the results are amazing. The plans of the new city aligned the mosque in Old Delhi with the famous roundabout of Connaught Place and the parliament. Inspired by the splendour of the Maharajas, Lutyens created a new style of urban architecture, combining the neoclassical with accents from the Mughal era and the Buddhist past.

Nalini Thakur, who specialises in the conservation of India's architectural heritage, described Lutyens' Delhi as 'a very rare capital of the early 20th century!' After the partition of India in 1947, when India regained its freedom, the morphology of Delhi changed. Delhi and its perpetual construction sites over the years has become the theatre of the contrasts of modern India. The large airy avenues of the British era co-exist with the urban hubbub and the maze of Old Delhi, whose streets are only wide enough to ride a scooter through. On Delhi's chaotic roads, it is not uncommon to see an elephant, ox carts, horse carriages, taxis, motorcycles, and rickshaws (tricycles), all competing for a bit of road space. In its frenetic race toward modernisation, Delhi is topsy-turvy. And forgive the word play when we say that Delhi is very much 'topsy' in terms of the cultural wonders it deploys. What a delight to strike out in this anarchic mosaic and explore Mughal mausoleums, Hindu and Sikh temples, dusty bazaars, majestic buildings from the British Raj era, and the fortresses and gardens that oxygenate the city. Delhi perfectly reflects the wise, ancient spirit of India through the teaching of Hinduism and yoga as well as the violence and modernity of its industrialisation process and technological prowess.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Delhi

seoData.seoTitle: New Delhi: the scent of India - New Delhi Travel Guide
seoData.seoDescription: New Delhi, the capital of India with a history that goes back to the Mahabharata, is a richly diverse melting pot of cultures, flavours and aromas that thrills the heart of travellers.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Delhi

content.title: Let's Bunk Poshtel, a fancy youth hostel

introduction.small: Ideally located across Delhi's Rose Garden, in the heart of Hauz Khas Village, Let's Bunk Poshtel reveals a stylish and modern universe, far from your usual hostel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Let's Bunk Poshtel, a fancy youth hostel

paragraphs.text:
As soon as step in, you will understand why all the clichés about youth hostels have no hold here! In the heart of the arty and trendy Hauz Khas Village in Delhi, Let's Bunk Poshtel really stands out, with a modern and pared-down look. The play on words in the name speaks for itself. The 11 bedrooms, from dormitories to private suites, give off a sense of minimalism, far the kitsch encountered in some other establishments. It offers precious calm in spite of its location in a lively neighbourhood, as all the rooms give onto the greenery of the National Rose Garden. During the day, connected travellers get comfortable in the shared room, graced with warm lighting. Nighttime events will then take the lead: for instance with Indian beer tastings – to be enjoyed in moderation – or film screenings. Do not miss the barbecues and concerts set up on the rooftop, with Hauz Khas Village and Deer Park as fantastic backdrops for a magical moment at sunset…

Let's Bunk Poshtel
T-40 Hauz Khaz Village
New Delhi
Delhi 110016

+91 (0)81 3038 3199

https://letsbunk.live/

Rooms: dormitory bed from 699 INR, private bedroom from 3,540 INR

content.title: Street art in Delhi, an open-air gallery

introduction.small: Explore another side of Delhi, with its urban landscape that changes to the rhythm of ephemeral and politically-inclined works of art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Street art in Delhi, an open-air gallery

paragraphs.text:
Former British colonial district in Delhi, The Lodhi became the first “Art District” of the country in 2016. Here, frescoes are the work of the biggest names of the street art scene, invited by the St+art Indian foundation. In this open-air museum, the association cares to open art art to all, at a time when traditional exhibition areas are somehow reserved for the Indian elite. Some graffiti deliver political messages, like Andreco's Climate 05, with its depiction of pollution.

Other neighbourhoods stand out with unique pieces, like the Delhi Police Headquarters, sheltering a 45-metre high black & white image of Gandhi! Hauz Khas Village et Shahpur Jat are alternative places where street corners are more and more covered in paint. More discreet, the frescoes of Connaught Place are also worth a look: amid this key shopping area, street art dealing with woman empowerment is especially thrilling. A must see!

https://st-artindia.org/city/delhi

content.title: Café Lota, authenticity and a hidden terrace

introduction.small: More than a simple museum cafeteria, Café Lota draws from the roots of Indian gastronomy and introduces a menu with many specialities from the northern regions of the country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Café Lota, authenticity and a hidden terrace

paragraphs.text:
Hidden amid the National Craft Museum, which is dedicated to Indian craftsmanship in Delhi, Café Lota offers a calm and serene atmosphere from the surrounding urban bustle. Under a large gazebo, the terrace is a haven of cool. Make sure you have a reservation to enjoy it, as it is very popular and in demand. Here, specialities of Indian gastronomy – especially from the north of the country – are prepared with a modern twist. The menu changes regularly, according to seasons and availability of local products. It will be hard to choose among roasted lotus steamed dumplings served with a yogurt cream, scallions and cashew nuts, the traditional Rajasthan chicken curry or the slow-cooked mutton in coconut milk and coriander… For sides, Café Lota sheds a light on ancient cereals: millet, red rice and amaranth will take you to the roots of Indian gastronomy. In this quest for authenticity, the restaurant also offers traditional breakfasts that you undoubtedly revel in!

Café Lota
National Crafts Museum, Gate No. 2
Bhairon Marg
Pragati Maidan
New Delhi
Delhi 110001

+91 (0)99 1080 7703

https://meltingpotfood.in/cafe-lota/

Menu: around 930 INR

content.title: Shahpur Jat, Delhi's trendiest market

introduction.small: In one of Delhi's most popular neighbourhoods, Shahpur Jat gathers fashion shops and all kinds of accessories.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shahpur Jat, Delhi's trendiest market

paragraphs.text:
Shahpur Jat has become the HQ for fashionistas around the world. Crowded night and day, this long alleyway gathers 200 some shops, one more original than the next. From suppliers of textiles to haute couture boutiques, dyers and weavers, you will find whatever you are looking for at Shahpur Jat! It is possible to bargain-hunt and find items at very affordable prices, pleasing a very cosmopolitan clientele composed of tourists and locals alike. More than 2,000 visitors visit the alley daily, expanding to 10,000 some during wedding season. The neighbourhood overflows with creativity and is well-known for the quality of formal dresses you can find.
In case you feel a bit thirsty, do not hesitate to stop at one of the charming cafes hidden amid the various shops. A hot drink plus a local pastry should recharge your batteries before resuming your crazy shopping spree!

Shahpur Jat
Siri Fort
New Delhi
Delhi 11004

content.title: Ministry of Beer, for a crazy night out

introduction.small: Located in the heart of New Delhi, Ministry of Beer is the stronghold of beer and finger food lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ministry of Beer, for a crazy night out

paragraphs.text:
Ministry of Beer, also known under the MOB acronym, is a restaurant-pub of industrial overtones in which sci-fiyish decoration looks straight out of Blade Runner or Metropolis. In order to break free from traditionally old school brasseries, owners Sagar Sharma and Prateek Chaturvedi wanted a quirky feel for their establishment, using mechanical objects, metal gears, Victorian furniture and iron-wrought lighting fixtures.

On the ground floor, the menu created by talented chef Meet Malhotra offers a large selection of dishes, either Indian, Asian or Western. Give the Lamb Chukka a try, a signature dish made with coconut and Chukka Masala, unless you fall for the lemon chicken, with garlic and black pepper, served with new potatoes infused and flambeed in white wine.
On the first floor, you will have a choice of craft beers or futuristic cocktails created by mixologist bartenders - to be enjoyed in moderation of course. The atmosphere is festive and you will surely feel like a few steps on the dancefloor before moving on to the terrace, the ideal location to enjoy the most amazing of views over New Delhi.

Ministry of Beer (MOB)
M-43, Outer Circle
Connaught Place
New Delhi
Delhi 110001

+91 (0)88 0001 2060

http://mobbrewpub.com/

Menu: from 995 INR

content.title: Step into the skin of Aishwarya Raï, the brightest of Bollywood stars

introduction.small: You may have looked upon them with amazement, enthusiasm and admiration. Now it is your turn to dance in Delhi, like the most beautiful dancers in these famous Indian dance movies.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Step into the skin of Aishwarya Raï, the brightest of Bollywood stars

paragraphs.text:
Embedded in the culture of the country, Indian classical dance is practiced by all generations and includes all kinds of dances: bharata natyam, kathak, kathakali, manipuri, kuchipudi and odissi as described in the ancient Nâtya-shâstra text. Idealised by the actors and actresses of Bollywood cinema, the various existing forms of dance have spread rapidly in the West where classes and workshops have multiplied.

Once in the heart of the Indian capital, you can experience this ancestral art of bewitching beauty and will become a traditional dancer if only for a moment. Women will don a sari, salwar-kameez, churidar or lengha and men a sherwani, kurta-pajama or dhoti! Register now at the renowned Delhi Dance Academy and, together with tourists and expatriates, take part in introductory workshops to Indian dance, with the support of professionals.

Delhi Dance Academy
Namaste India Dance Workshop
E238 Amar Colony
Lajpat Nagar 4

+91 (0)11 4101 2909

www.delhidanceacademy.in/dance-classes-expats-foreigners-delhi

content.title: The Lotus Temple blooms in the eyes of the world

introduction.small: Pride of the Baha'i community, the Lotus Temple brings together believers of all horizons around a universal and peaceful faith.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Lotus Temple blooms in the eyes of the world

paragraphs.text:
As you approach the Lotus Temple, the concrete petals seem to open up into the nine surrounding pools of turquoise water, harmoniously lit by the Indian sun. A symbol of immortality, purity and love, this immense lotus flower brings together tourists and the faithful in the south of Delhi.

Designed by the architect Fariborz Sahba when he was just 28 years old, this marble temple invites you to admire the work of 800 workmen that created the structure, finishing in 1986, the year of its inauguration.

The highlight of the visit is the prayer room, with its immaculate walls bathed in light, with no representation of God. On the highest point of the structure, on a decorative plaque is the gilded name of the founder of the faith, Bahá'u'lláh. In the heart of the capital, this 20th-century spiritual masterpiece reflects the tolerance of Indians for all religions.

Lotus Temple
Lotus Temple Road
Shambhu Dayal Bagh
Bahapur
New Delhi
Delhi 110019

+91 (0)11 2644 4029

www.bahaihouseofworship.in

content.title: Jain Charity Birds Hospital, temple of flight

introduction.small: Visit a place unique in the world: the Jain Charity Birds Hospital, a hospital that heals the birds of Delhi!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jain Charity Birds Hospital, temple of flight

paragraphs.text:
In India, it is said that the soul of a bird is worth that of a king. Located in the Digambar complex, the Jain Charity Birds Hospital welcomes and cares for many birds saved by inhabitants of Delhi. Here, these birds, considered "noble", are pampered and venerated, while every day, a quarantine is conducted in this hospice of a somewhat particular kind. However different they may be, all birds are accepted: parakeets, chickens, pigeons, sparrows, parrots, falcons... In Delhi, men and women pay real attention to their well-being.
Built in 1956, the hospital has a capacity to hold 3,000 birds, which can stay for up to several months. Over the past 20 years, nearly 66,200 feathered patients have been put back on their feet (to take flight with their wings). If you wish to visit this absolutely unique place, you can attend the care and distribution of meals between 8:00 a.m. and 8 p.m.

Jain Charity Birds Hospital
Gonica World
Navin Shahdara
Delhi 110032

http://charitybirdshospital.org

content.title: Andhra Pradesh Bhavan, South-Indian food at its finest

introduction.small: In New Delhi, all the flavours of India converge. Andhra Pradesh Bhavan is one of the best places to discover southern-style Indian cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Andhra Pradesh Bhavan, South-Indian food at its finest

paragraphs.text:
With its tiled walls and bare decor, Andhra Pradesh Bhavan doesn't look like much: just another Indian canteen, like so many others in the city. But the impatient crowd clamouring to get inside for lunch is a good indicator of its quality. Every day, an armada of waiters perform a formidable and well-rehearsed ballet where the specialties of South India have a central role. The traditional thali with dal and chutney, served in metal containers, has pride of place. On Sundays, spicy chicken biryani from the Hyderabad region is the star of the menu, but the fish and mutton curries are just as good, so delicious in fact that you will forget the hubbub of the room, crowded with people from all walks of New Delhi life.

Andhra Pradesh Bhavan Canteen
1, Ashoka Road
New Delhi
Delhi 110001

+91 (0)11 2338 2031

Menu: around 100 INR

content.title: Bloom Rooms, Delhi chic with a French Touch

introduction.small: Exclusive design, comfort, and central location: Bloom Rooms offers a truly affordable luxury.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bloom Rooms, Delhi chic with a French Touch

paragraphs.text:
In the middle of bustling New Delhi, just a stone's throw from the Railway Station, Bloom Rooms is unlike any other hotel in the Indian capital-and for good reason-the atypical decoration is by Amaury Watine and Stephanie Bonduelle, two young French designers who have imported a new French Touch to Delhi by creating their own agency. The result is particularly refreshing: immaculate Art-Deco architecture mixes well with the beautiful bright 1960s yellow furniture, organised around a very nice courtyard. This three-star spot has it all: impeccable bedding, rain showers, very chic English bath products, iMacs in the lobby, Wi-Fi and a 24-hour reception area to take care of all your needs.

Bloom Rooms
8591 Arakashan Road
New Delhi 110055

+91 (0)11 4017 4017

https://staybloom.com/hotellanding/delhi-bloomrooms-new-delhi-railway-station

Rooms: from 2,250 INR

content.title: Akshardham Temple: temple of excess

introduction.small: Askhardham temple is a contemporary building that traces 10,000 years of the eternal traditions and beliefs of Indian and Hindu culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Akshardham Temple: temple of excess

paragraphs.text:
Akshardham Temple was built in honour of the founder of the Hindu religion, Swaminarayan Sampraday. It stands on the banks of the Yamuna river. Inaugurated in 2005, the temple, which embodies the beauty and greatness of Hindu culture, consists of 6,000 tons of pink sandstone from Rajasthan and has 234 carved pillars, nine domes, and 20,000 murtis (figures of deities carved in stone). It took 900 craftsmen, 7,000 workers, 3,000 volunteers and 12 million hours of work to finish a colossal building site for a sumptuous result.

There is no cement or concrete, only gold, marble, and sandstone. Go through the door of devotion, Bhakti Dwar, then, that of the peacock, Mayur Dwar, before reaching the Garden of Eden. Through various exhibitions, discover the life of the founder of Hinduism and its teachings. Do not be surprised if, in this temple of excess, you come across a cinema and musical fountains. In India, spirituality manifests itself in infinite forms.

Akshardham Temple
Noida Mor
New Delhi
Delhi 110092

+91 (0)11 4344 2344

https://akshardham.com/

content.title: Qûtb Minâr, a spectacular mosque

introduction.small: An architectural ensemble of tombs and religious buildings, the Qûtb Minâr's famous minaret celebrates the victory of a Muslim sultan.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Qûtb Minâr, a spectacular mosque

paragraphs.text:
Built in the early 13th century, Qutb Minar's minaret is the tallest in India. This victory tower rises over four floors to nearly 73 metres, with a diameter of 15 metres at the base and 2.50 metres at the top. This architectural feat was conceived at the initiative of the Mehrauli sultans who wished to strengthen the power of the Muslim state through stonework. It was hard work for Hindu craftsmen, who had to shape the rock, carving ornamental motifs and the calligraphy of the Koranic verses by hammering the surface.

On the archaeological site you will explore the tombs, the magnificent Alai-Darwaza, a masterpiece of Indo-Muslim art built in 1311, and two mosques, including that of Quwwat-ul-Islam. The latter is the oldest in northern India and was built with materials from twenty Brahman temples.


Qûtb Minâr
Mehrauli
New Delhi
Delhi 110030

+91 (0)11 2469 8431

www.delhitourism.gov.in/delhitourism/tourist_place/qutab_minar.jsp

content.title: Imperial, that's a Palace!

introduction.small: Built in 1934, the Imperial Hotel was an important part of India's history in the era of the maharajas and British settlers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Imperial, that's a Palace!

paragraphs.text:
Once frequented by Gandhi, Nehru, Jinnah, and Mountbatten, the Imperial Hotel continues to attract many dignitaries and celebrities who, after coming up the driveway lined with 24 palm trees, are greeted ceremoniously by a hunter with the same moustache as Rajput, son of the Prince of Rajasthan.

In the marble clad lobby with its grandiose columns, the smell of jasmine will awaken your senses. Each time you walk past a member of staff they greet you by folding their hands and bowing their heads, giving you the sudden feeling of what it must have been like to be a real-life maharajah. The dream continues in any of the hotel's 192 rooms and 43 suites. Most are in the Art Deco style with a slight Victorian touch. At breakfast in the morning, you can hear the birds singing in the garden, making you feel far away from the city.

Imperial Hotel
Janpath Ln
Connaught Place
New Delhi
Delhi 110001

+91 11 2334 1234

https://theimperialindia.com/

Rooms: from 11,000 INR

content.title: In the footsteps of Gandhi

introduction.small: No need to undertake the salt march to walk in the footsteps of Mahatma Gandhi. Just visit the legendary places that pay tribute to the liberator of India.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the footsteps of Gandhi

paragraphs.text:
In Hindi, Mahatma means ‘great soul,' and it is to this greatness of soul that you pay tribute to by visiting the Raj Ghat. Located south of the Red Fort on the banks of the Yamuna, this memorial is where Gandhi, who was brutally murdered in 1948, was cremated. An eternal flame burns at one end of the slab of black marble.

Not far away, the National Gandhi Museum also pays moving tribute to Mahatma through his photos and personal effects, like his dhoti and his spinning wheel.

In Safdarjung Enclave, stop by the Gandhi Smriti, which houses the Birla House, where he stayed the last 144 days of his life.

After the tears, go into the Khadi Gramodyog store where cotton, silk, and wool are woven in the finest tradition of the Father of the Nation, using the famous ‘Charkha' spinning wheel.

Raj Ghat
Mahatma Gandhi Road
New Delhi‬
Delhi 110006
+91 (0)11 2567 5609
http://rajghat.gov.in/

Gandhi Museum
Raj Ghat, Vikram Nagar
New Delhi
Delhi 110002
+91 (0)11 2331 0168
http://gandhimuseum.org

Gandhi Smriti
5, Tees January Lane
New Delhi
Delhi 110001
+91 (0)11 2301 2843

Khadi Gramodyog Bhavan
Shop No. A-1, Emporia Complex
Baba Kharak Singh Marg
Connaught Place
New Delhi
Delhi 110001

content.title: Trident Gurgaon Hotel: an oasis in the urban jungle

introduction.small: Temple of excellence and good taste, the Trident Gurgaon Hotel is a favourite of travellers in the know.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Trident Gurgaon Hotel: an oasis in the urban jungle

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the business district of Gurgaon, just 30 minutes from the international airport, the Trident Gurgaon Hotel is an ideal stopover to counter jet lag.

An architectural marvel, it deploys contemporary decor throughout 136 rooms and suites, surrounded by 2.8 hectares of gardens, tree-lined patios, ponds and fountains. Here, everything is tranquil, and the traveller feels as if wrapped in a sweet cocoon. Enjoy the splendid cuisine of all three of the hotel's restaurants: the international cuisine at Cilantro; top-notch Indian at Saffron; and, finally, Konomi for fans of sushi and sashimi. Yoga classes are given each morning to greet the sun.

Try to get room 412 if you can. This deluxe room overlooks a pool and comes with a butler to meet your every whim.

Trident Gurgaon Hotel
443 Udyog Vihar
Phase V
Gurgaon
Haryana 122016

+91 (0)12 4245 0505

https://www.tridenthotels.com/hotels-in-gurgaon

Rooms: from 10,000 INR

content.title: The Leela Palace: an eccentric palace hotel

introduction.small: Once part of the Kempinski group, the Leela became independent in 2013 and has won over many enthusiasts with its original, unique luxury.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Leela Palace: an eccentric palace hotel

paragraphs.text:
Built in 2001 in the prestigious Diplomatic Enclave, Leela Palace is the jewel of the Indian capital. It dominates the city with its imposing size and architecture, the latter largely inspired by Sir Edwin Lutyens, the man who, under British imperial governance, built New Delhi's Indian Gate and Rashtrapati Bhavan, now the residence of the Indian president.

The Leela has redefined luxury: it boasts four gourmet restaurants, including the very successful Qube and its show kitchens, a two-floor spa offering Ayurvedic treatments and a heated pool on the roof, famous art works from all over the world, and a particularly attentive staff. Fusion is in the Leela's DNA it merges classic Indian elegance with touches of eccentricity, modernity and customised services, like… astrologer or numerologist consultations. With 254 deluxe rooms, including several suites with private pools, the Leela is where you can completely relax.

The Leela Palace
Africa Avenue
Chanakyapuri
Diplomatic Enclave
New Delhi
Delhi 110023

+91 (0)11 3933 1234

www.theleela.com/en_us/

Rooms: from 17,325 INR

content.title: Oberoi New Delhi: view from a palace

introduction.small: The Oberoi New Delhi, located between Delhi's golf course and Humayun's Tomb, was one of the first luxury hotels in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oberoi New Delhi: view from a palace

paragraphs.text:
Haloed in light, the sumptuous and welcoming lobby houses a majestic sculpture called ‘Tree of Life', which asks for peace, serenity, and spirituality for travellers.

The modern building is surrounded by a forest of palm trees and overlooks the beautiful Delhi Golf Club for those who love their 'tee time'. This big white block of a building contains 220 rooms, all decorated in shades of champagne, beige, and caramel, culminating in the 32-square-metre Kohinoor suite. As in all the hotels in the Oberoi chain, the staff is attentive.

Accompanied by a guide from the hotel, explore the streets of Old Delhi and visit Chandni Chowk, a colourful market redolent with aromas and flavours. Massage, hydrotherapy, and Turkish baths are offered in a Spa of more than 800 square metres. At the Oberoi, space is a luxury you will never get tired of.

Oberoi New Delhi
Dr. Zakir Hussain Marg
New Delhi
Delhi 110003

+91 (0)11 2436 3030

www.oberoihotels.com/hotels-in-delhi/

Rooms: from 11,500 INR

content.title: 1911 Restaurant & Bar: the royal road

introduction.small: Awarded best whiskey bar in 2012, 1911 is an absolute must in Delhi, just like the restaurant of the same name.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 1911 Restaurant & Bar: the royal road

paragraphs.text:
1911 refers to the year when New Delhi became, once again, 200 years later, the capital of India.

The year is celebrated in the decor, through antiques, photographs, and lithographs; 1911 also being the year when King George V and his queen were crowned emperors of India at Durbar.

Spread over three areas in an Art Deco style, the restaurant serves world cuisine, and the waiters wear royal guard uniforms. The bar is stocked with more than 500 varieties of eaux-de-vie, whiskey, and, of course, India's national cocktail, the Gimlet (gin and lemon). That this place was voted best whiskey bar in the world by Whisky Magazine in 2012 comes as no surprise.

1911 Restaurant & Bar
The Imperial
Janpath Lane
Connaught Place
110001 ‎New Delhi

+91 11 2334 1234

https://theimperialindia.com/restaurant-menu/1911-restaurant/

Menu: from 3,550 INR

content.title: The Lodhi: the crème de la crème of contemporary palace hotels

introduction.small: Formerly the Aman Delhi and renamed The Lodhi in 2013, this hotel retains all the advantages of a luxury resort.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Lodhi: the crème de la crème of contemporary palace hotels

paragraphs.text:
Staying at the Lodhi is an outstanding experience.

After the 40-minute drive from the airport, your heart will stop beating at the sight of the hotel's modern, minimalist architecture. Stroll through these two imposing buildings whose walls are interspersed with jali, carved stone screens that filter the rays of the soft Indian light.

The 36 hectares of greenery are an oasis in the heart of the Indian metropolis. In this unique landscape, the contemporary and the traditional merge: in the courtyard, bamboo gardens embellish a shining mineral-blue swimming pool. The rooms feature cosy furnishings against a marble floor. Beauty, ‘minerality', elegance, and pleasure characterise this sumptuous sanctuary, right in Delhi.

The Lodhi
Lodhi Road
Pragati Vihar
New Delhi
Delhi 110003

+91 (0)11 4363 3333

www.thelodhi.com

Rooms: from 13,800 INR

content.title: Yoga, the spiritual food of India

introduction.small: Yoga is one of six major philosophical systems called ‘darshanas', which means ‘look at the world.'

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yoga, the spiritual food of India

paragraphs.text:
The word 'yoga' comes from the ancient Sanskrit root 'jug', which can be translated as 'connect the body, heart, and mind.' Yoga was developed more than 5,000 years ago. Since then, it has fit itself perfectly into everyday daily life. At the rising of the sun, like a proper yogi, practise the 'sun salutation' and, at nightfall, a cycle of 'moon salutations' followed by a meditation session. There are more than a hundred yoga variants, most taught in different centres in Delhi.

Sivananda Yoga is a reputable place, located in a bungalow-cum-ashram. Here, you string together different stretching postures, inversions, and twists and, for experienced yogis, the headstand or sirsasana. The Yogakshema Centre teaches Master Guru Ji, alias BKS Iyengar's fire tradition. These posture alignment courses are called Iyengar yoga.

Sivananda Yoga
A-41, Kailash Colony, Behind Metro Station
New Delhi
Delhi 110048
+91 11 4059 1221
www.sivananda.org.in/delhi

Iyengar Yogakshema
Plot No.65,66,67, Indian Heritage Society
Deendayal Upadhyay Marg
Rouse Avenue
New Delhi
Delhi 110002
+91 11 2323 4356
www.iyengaryogakshema.org

content.title: Veda: restaurant-cum-bar-lounge

introduction.small: Contemporary Indian-influenced classic cuisine in a reinterpreted Bollywood palace decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Veda: restaurant-cum-bar-lounge

paragraphs.text:
Veda restaurant gives the cuisine of the Indian subcontinent pride of place by reinterpreting it in a contemporary way. Each of the dishes is a full experience. If you are fond of vegetables, you have a tasting menu of eight gourmet dishes, including shrimp biryani in fish masala and ending with a sorbet to help digestion.

The talented fashion designer, Rohit Bal, has transformed the place into a restaurant and bar with shimmering, opulent decor. Brick, red lighting, mirrors, and a subtle ambience make this a sublimely beautiful place, mixing Bollywood and gypsy punk influences.

Behind the flashy restaurant is the bar, serving speciality cocktails such as the Litchi'n'Crush, made of litchi juice, vodka and coconut water.

Veda
H27, Tropical Building
Connaught Circus
Connaught Place
Delhi 110001

+91 (0)11 4151 3535

www.vedarestaurants.com

Menu: from 1,100 INR

content.title: Fatehpur Sikri: ghost town

introduction.small: A temporary capital during the reign of King Akbar, Fatehpur Sikri and its vestiges are an important part of the history of the Mughal Empire.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fatehpur Sikri: ghost town

paragraphs.text:
According to legend, in 1568, King Akbar, who seemed doomed not to have any offspring, went to consult with a Sufi saint in the town of Sikri. A few years later, three heirs were born to him.

Out of gratitude to this holy man, the king built the city of Fatehpur Sikri, literally ‘city of victory'. For nearly 10 years, Fatehpur Sikri was the capital of the Mughal Empire, but it was abandoned by its creator for lack of an adequate water supply. This village, which was inhabited for four centuries, has numerous architectural splendours. Behind the door of Agra, you will visit several tombs that are sumptuous palaces, like that of Jodha Bai, wife of Akbar and daughter of the Maharaja of Jodhpur, or that of Panch Mahal, all of carved wood with a triangular silhouette. North of the plaza, you will cross the hall where private hearings take place, the Diwan-i-Khas, whose centre is marked by a majestic column. And, nearby is the Great Mosque or Jama Masjid, known for its sublime door and openwork screens.

content.title: Shekhawati, an endangered open-air museum

introduction.small: The buildings and decor were abandoned for ages: the ‘haveli' of Shekhawati.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shekhawati, an endangered open-air museum

paragraphs.text:
At the gates of the Thar Desert, squeezed between the Aravalli hills of the Shekhawati region are the villages of Nawalgarh, Jhunjhunu, Mahansar, Mandawa, and Fatehpur. Desperately, they display the still-magnificent frescoes and murals of their decrepit palaces, called "haveli".

Between 1860 and 1900, these rich mansions were built by the merchants of Shekhawati to show off their business success. Gradually abandoned by their owners, these villages have become veritable ghost towns. Today, some of the families and guardians of these palatial mansions open their doors to travellers. In the pretty market town of Nawalgarh, discover a sumptuous palace with impressive frescoes. A blend of Rajput and Anglo-Indian art, these paintings depict legends, epics, great battles, processions, and traditional scenes. Continue your journey by visiting the Sardul Singh Cenotaph at Parasarampura, then double back to the Podar Haveli Museum at Dundlod.

Shekhawati
Ath Haveli
Nansa Gate Rajasthan
Nawalgargh 333042

content.title: Delhi Food Walks: the taste of India

introduction.small: The city is marked by several gustatory itineraries through which the traveller discovers the culinary specialties of the gastronomic scene.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Delhi Food Walks: the taste of India

paragraphs.text:
Are you ready to awaken your taste buds to the colours, sounds and, of course, tastes of the market stalls, lively streets, and famous street corners of street food?

From ice cream to beer, and fruit to meatballs, Delhi Food Walks' experienced guides will show you Delhi's ‘fooding' scene. All tours are customisable and can be adapted to your desires. From morning until evening, you can try the Breakfast Trail, which shows you breakfast in all its forms, or the Gurudwara Walk, which is named at the Sikh temple, and introduces you to the roti flat bread and daal (lentil curry) of Sikh cuisine.

A unique experience awaits you, one in which Delhi sensually reveals itself to you with every forkful.

Delhi Food Walks
Chandni Chowk
Near Paranthe Wali gali
New Delhi
Delhi 110006

+91 (0)98 9112 1333

www.delhifoodwalks.com/

content.title: National Gallery of Modern Art: a day at the museum

introduction.small: The National Gallery of Modern Art (NGMA) has offered the best modern and contemporary Indian art since 1954.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: National Gallery of Modern Art: a day at the museum

paragraphs.text:
The NGMA headquarters are in the former residential palace of the Maharaja of Jaipur. The architect of Jaipur House, Sir Arthur Bloomfield, was largely inspired by the buildings of New Delhi designed by Edwin Lutyens. At the heart of this royal jewel shines a magnificent collection of paintings, some dating back more than 150 years. Paintings, sculptures, drawings, and photographs a total of more than 15,000 works coexist in this timeless place. In the sumptuous rooms of the palace are numerous treasures.

Admire the work of British painter Thomas Daniell; the post-Impressionist paintings of Jamini Roy, student of the famous artist Abanindranath Tagore; and the work of Amrita Sher-Gil, often compared to that of the Mexican Frida Kahlo. In terms of international artists, the collection includes works by Jacob Epstein, Giorgio de Chirico, Petar Lubarda, Henry Moore, Sonia Delaunay, and Kozo Mio.

National Gallery of Modern Art (NGMA)
Jaipur House
India Gate, Near Delhi High Court
New Delhi
Delhi 110 003

+91 (0)11 2338 2835

http://ngmaindia.gov.in

content.title: The Ambassador, a former colonial-era hotel

introduction.small: Built in 1945, the Ambassador Hotel combines colonial and Art Deco styles alongside gardens lined with palm trees.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Ambassador, a former colonial-era hotel

paragraphs.text:
Very 'old school' and a tad out-dated, the Ambassador (short for Ambassador, New Delhi - IHCL SeleQtions) remains one of the most affordable of the SeleQtions chain hotels in Delhi.

This one is a favourite with businessmen who like its central location. You can easily visit the city's points of interest from here, such as The Red Fort, the Mughal Emperor's Tomb, Sunder Nagar Market, and Khan Market. The hotel's chic canteen, Yellow Brick Road, is open round the clock.

There are 88 rooms, including 14 suites with balconies overlooking the garden or the courtyard. All are decorated with a dark wood reminiscent of the colonial atmosphere that reigned here for decades. The only downside: the hotel does not have a pool to refresh body and mind.

Ambassador, New Delhi - IHCL SeleQtions
Sujan Singh Park
Subramaniam Bharti Marg
New Delhi
Delhi 110003

+91 (0)11 6626 1000

https://www.seleqtionshotels.com/en-in/ambassador-new-delhi/

Rooms: from 5,700 INR

content.title: Mittal Tea House: a merchant of teas and marvels

introduction.small: In India, tea or ‘chai' is the local drink; it is offered on every street corner as a gesture of welcome.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mittal Tea House: a merchant of teas and marvels

paragraphs.text:
Mittal Tea House was one of the first shops to sell loose leaf tea in Delhi. It was formerly a general store founded in 1954 by Lieutenant Shri B.D.

Mittal converted it into a teashop in the 1970s. His son, Vikram Mittal, joined the business and became a specialist in dried tea tree leaves. He led several conferences and everywhere defended the idea that tea is highly tonic, full of qualities and virtues that make people happier. Behind the small white counter of the shop, you will always be greeted with a smile and spoiled for choice, with all the varieties of tea available. On the menu are, of course, Indian teas such as Darjeeling, Assam, and Nilgiri-both flavoured and unflavoured-as well as herbal teas, infusions, and other teas from China, Japan, Sri Lanka and South Africa.

Mittal Tea House
Shop No. 8 Main Market, Block 8
Lodi Colony
New Delhi
Delhi 110003

+91 (0)11 2461 5709

https://mittalteahouse.com

content.title: Goodearth, Meharchand Market, Sharma Farm: chic bazaars

introduction.small: Several bazaars are still found among high-end boutiques specialising in decor, ready-to-wear, fabrics, and furniture for a little piece of India at home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Goodearth, Meharchand Market, Sharma Farm: chic bazaars

paragraphs.text:
Goodearth has a very refined collection, whose iconic drawing, interlaced palms, is inspired by the magic lake of Periyar in Kerala and the lush vegetation of the Malabar coast.

Meharchand Market stretches out along Lodhi Road, where you will get lost in the many stalls, a veritable compendium of the new India, with creations by talented local jewellers, Anuradha Ramam saris or ikats, January Rose slippers, the CMYK bookstore, and wild fashion designs by Pia Pauro. Finally, look for hidden gems in the huge Sharma Farm market. In a large hangar, light fixtures, mirrors, decorative objects, and antique furnishings of all sorts are for sale.

If you need to ship your purchases, do not worry; Sharma Farm takes care of everything. Incredible India!

Goodearth
S-06, A-3 District Centre
3rd Floor Select City Walk Mall
Saket
Delhi 110017
+91 (0)11 4053 4567
www.goodearth.in

Meharchand Market

Delhi 110003

Sharma Farm

New Delhi

content.title: Bukhara: a place to see and be seen

introduction.small: The ‘Times' newspaper calls the Bukhara a VIP hangout. No wonder, given It has served guests like Bill Clinton and Bill Gates.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bukhara: a place to see and be seen

paragraphs.text:
Considered one of the best traditional Indian restaurants in Delhi, the Bukhara surprises gourmets with its legendary dal. Dal bukhara is a black lentil curry whose cooking time exceeds 17 hours. Its tandoori dishes, from northwest India, are also stunning

Tandoori is difficult to perfect because the meat is marinated, then cooked in a clay oven without the addition of any liquid or sauce. The restaurant has an open kitchen where chefs in their great white hats twirl naans and braise chicken in full view. No white tablecloths here, only sturdy dark wood trays, scattered cushions, and low tables in a calm and relaxed atmosphere.

Welcome to Bukhara, the in-house restaurant of Hotel ITC Maurya New Delhi, where you will have an authentic experience that is chic and rustic.

Bukhara
Hotel ITC Maurya
Sardar Patel Marg
Akhaura Block
Diplomatic Enclave
Chanakyapuri
New Delhi
Delhi 110021

+91 (0)11 2611 2233

https://www.itchotels.in/hotels/new-delhi/itcmaurya/dining/bukhara.html

Menu: around 1,575 INR

content.title: Agra, the palace of love

introduction.small: The city of Agra and the Taj Mahal are inseparable, but Agra is also home to a beautiful fort from the Mughal period.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Agra, the palace of love

paragraphs.text:
In 1631, Shah Jahan, the famous Mughal emperor, was devastated by the death during childbirth of his third wife. He decided to build in her honour the most beautiful mausoleum in the world, the Taj Mahal. The story goes that more than a thousand elephants carried the sandstone, marble, jade, turquoise, sapphire, and other materials used to build it. The writer Rabindranath Tagore describes the palace of love as ‘a tear suspended on the cheek of time'.

In 1658, the emperor was overthrown by his son Aurangzeb and imprisoned in Fort Agra, also known as the ‘Red Fort', which was built by King Akbar in 1565. With the emperor's death in 1666, his remains were placed close to that of his beloved wife. Shah Jahan's youngest son extended Fort Agra by adding palaces and mosques of white marble. Today, the army occupies the site, but you can visit the southeast part where, through openwork screens, the sparkling silhouette of the Taj Mahal looms on the horizon.

Taj Mahal
Uttar Pradesh
Agra 282001
+91 (0)56 2222 6431
www.tajmahal.gov.in/

Fort Agra
Rakabganj
Uttar Pradesh
Agra 282003
+91 (0)56 2296 0457
www.agrafort.gov.in/indexNew/index.html

content.title: The Manor: 1950s chic

introduction.small: In the chic and somewhat eccentric enclave of New Friends Colony, The Manor offers more than a dozen rooms with a designer feel and pure tranquillity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Manor: 1950s chic

paragraphs.text:
Within the stylish confines of the New Friends Colony neighbourhood is The Manor, a boutique hotel.

This 1950s building began as a simple country hotel but is now an urban refuge. A large landscaped garden surrounds the hotel, with its dark wood decor and caramel tones. This 14-room hotel was designed by Shirley Fujikawa of London's Studio U + A and Vinay Kappoor. They have created a place of luxury and serenity. Since the hotel is a bit out of the way, your stay will be all the better because you will have time to enjoy the hotel. The bar, for instance, serves delicious cocktails.

The Manor
77, Friends Colony West
Near Old Friend's Club
New Delhi
Delhi 110065

+91 (0)11 4687 7777

www.themanordelhi.com

Rooms: from 7,499 INR

content.title: Amarya Villa: India ‘Made in France'

introduction.small: In 2010, a French couple opened this Franco-Indian boutique hotel in south Delhi.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Amarya Villa: India ‘Made in France'

paragraphs.text:
In Safdarjung area, there is a small boutique hotel of nine guest rooms, each with a different decor based on the theme of Navratnas nine auspicious gems with astrological significance.

The hotel consists of two three-storey villas with a sleek urban aesthetic. Read, chat and while away the day in the beautiful garden with its gleaming lawn, or on the terrace in a Muda, a typical Indian armchair of woven cane. A French-style breakfast is available all day: organic eggs, soft bread, delicious pancakes, fresh fruit salads and freshly squeezed juices. Sheltered from the bustle of the city, this gem of a hotel is quiet, relaxed, serene, and stylish.

Amarya Villa
A2/20 Safdarjung Enclave
New Delhi
Delhi 110029

+91 (0)99 9907 1491

https://amaryagroup.wixsite.com/amaryagroup/amaryavilla

Rooms: from 4,900 INR

content.title: Chandni Chowk: temple of street food

introduction.small: There are several stalls at Chandni Chowk that cater to the delight of travellers who come to the market to savour the flavours of India.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chandni Chowk: temple of street food

paragraphs.text:
If you want to eat the best Indian street food, go to the oldest market of Old Delhi, Chandni Chowk. There, enjoy the food at Natraj Dahi Bhalla, which serves the best dahi bhalla in the city.

Also known as dahi vada, this dish consists of lentil dumplings served with whipped yogurt cream and topped with sweet and spicy chutney. For fans of the samosa fritters stuffed with vegetables or meat head to another famous market stand called the Old Famous Jalebi Wala. If you have a sweet tooth, check out Kuremal Mohan Lal Kulfi Wale, which, since 1908, has often won the prize for best kulfi or ice cream.

Kake Di Hatti, meanwhile, makes the biggest naans in all of Delhi: the puffed bread dough is baked in a hot oven, right in front of your eyes.

Chandni Chowk Market
Kaccha Bagh Area
Old Delhi
Delhi 110006

content.title: In the footsteps of Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan

introduction.small: At the height of the Mughal Empire, Shah Jahan, ‘King of the World' in Persian, built architectural wonders in Delhi.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the footsteps of Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan

paragraphs.text:
In 1638, Emperor Shah Jahan decided to make Delhi the capital.

Erected in 1570, his great-grandfather's mausoleum, Humayun's Tomb, and his Persian gardens were the inspiration for the Taj Mahal. During your visit, you will be struck by the beauty of the 17 majestic arches and the domed roof, characteristic of Mughal art. In the Old Delhi neighbourhood, visit the Red Fort, and be dazzled by its many colours: the monument transforms from pink at dawn to purple in the setting sun. Go through the door of the fort, the Lahore Gate, then stroll through the Chatta Chowk bazaar; visit the home of the drum, Naubat Tahore; explore the house of Public Grievances, Diwan-i-Am, and the house for Private Hearings, Diwan-i-Khas.

In the latter, you will read the words engraved by Shah Jahan: 'If there is a paradise on earth, it is here.' And, finally, take in the largest mosque in India, the Jama Masjid, perched on a high terrace overlooking Old Delhi.

Humayun's Tomb
Mathura Road
Nizamuddin
New Delhi
Delhi 110013
+91 (0)11 2464 7005
www.humayunstomb.com/


The Red Fort

Chandni Chowk

Jama Masjid
Chandni Chowk

+91 (0)11 2336 5358
www.delhitourism.gov.in/delhitourism/tourist_place/jama_masjid.jsp

content.title: Indian Accent: possibly the best Indian restaurant in the city

introduction.small: With its innovative approach, Indian Accent is considered one of the best Indian restaurants in Asia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Indian Accent: possibly the best Indian restaurant in the city

paragraphs.text:
Located on the grounds of The Lodhi, Indian Accent was named best Asian-Indian restaurant by San Pellegrino's World's Best Restaurants Awards.

The success belongs to talented top chef Manish Mehrotra, who has invented a new form of Indian cuisine. Tradition and adventure go hand in hand throughout this multi-course menu of myriad flavours, like the roasted beetroot in masala and peanut butter, or the crab in tamarind coupled with a coconut curry. You will love it! From time to time, the chef tempers his meal with a soft Indian ice cream called kulfi. It is so good at India Accent that Manish Mehrotra brought it to the Hotel Parker Meridien in New York in 2016.

Indian Accent
The Lodhi
Lodhi Road
New Delhi
Delhi 110003

+91 (0)98 7111 7968

https://indianaccent.com/newdelhi/index.php

Menu: from 2,600 INR

content.title: Perfume Library, Kama Ayurveda, Gulab Singh Johrimal: India's multiple scents

introduction.small: Pasolini's famous ‘scent of India,' can be understood through an olfactory journey through three stores.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Perfume Library, Kama Ayurveda, Gulab Singh Johrimal: India's multiple scents

paragraphs.text:
An homage to the talented writer and film director, Pier Paolo Pasolini, who, in the 1960s, roamed the country with his friend Moravia and captured their travels in a literary masterpiece called The Scent of India. After this journey through three ‘sensational' addresses, you too will be enveloped, captured, and intoxicated by this scent of India. The first stop is at the rare and exclusive Perfume Library. Nearly 3,000 years of the history of fragrances are told through these scents concocted by designer Jahnvi Damaran Nadam. The second stop is at Kama Ayurveda, the temple of essences of flowers, plants, and spices that come in creams, balms, and massage oils. As for Gulab Singh Johrimal in Old Delhi, this third store claims to be the oldest fragrance merchant in India: it has sold attar (‘fragrance' in Hindi), as well as incense and soaps, since 1816.

Perfume Library
Shop n° 9 A.B.C. Ground
1st and 2nd floors
Khan Market

Kama Ayurveda

www.kamaayurveda.com

Gulab Singh Johrimal

Katra Mashru

content.title: Jaipur, the pink city

introduction.small: Jaipur embodies the essence of Indian culture. To experience it is a 48-hour marathon!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jaipur, the pink city

paragraphs.text:
Jaipur, with its three million inhabitants, is full of energy and mythical places to discover. Early in the morning, after dodging scooters, taxis, elephants, and camels, visit the fabric stalls of the Bapu Bazaar or the clothing and jewellery stalls at Johari Bazaar. Make a pilgrimage to Gem Palace, jeweller of the Kasliwal family for eight generations. There, contemplate exceptional antique jewellery, maharajas' chests, and precious gems. For lunch, give yourself a break at Anokhi café, the mecca of light snacks. Your afternoon will be taken up by two tours: the Wind Palace (Hawa Mahal), and the City Palace, which is still the residence of the royal family.

Dine out at Bar Palladio, where a refreshing cuisine is served, before going to sleep in one of the 11 rooms at 47 Jobner Bagh, a chic cocoon hotel. The next day, lose yourself in the fort and the cenotaphs at Amber. 11 kilometres away from Jaipur and perched atop a hill, the building guards the Raj Palace. Some say it is actually the most gigantic fort in the world after Gwalior.

To complete this journey, venture out to Samode and spend the night in Samode Palace, a former Rajput-Mughal palace whose building, at dusk, is brilliantly lit.

Bapu Bazaar
Bapu Market
Pink City
Rajasthan
Jaipur 302003

content.title: Le Bistrot du Parc: a French bistro

introduction.small: Bistrot du Parc is a Franco-Indian alliance of taste, worthy of Paris's ‘bistronomic' trend.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Bistrot du Parc: a French bistro

paragraphs.text:
Naina Bois-Juzan, a young Franco-Indian, born and raised in Paris, wanted to bring a Parisian bistro to India.

It was a daring and crazy gamble that has paid off brilliantly. Here, you can almost breathe the air of Paris. In a typical Parisian brasserie decor that includes Thonet chairs and round tables, squeeze in and indulge your craving for French food. The menu features seven starters, seven courses and seven desserts. All ingredients come from organic farms in Delhi, the dishes are prepared according to the rules of the French culinary arts and the personnel have been trained in French hotellerie style. It is a French touch that has won the hearts of Delhi.

Le Bistrot du Parc
Shop n° 57,58,59, A Block
Moolchand Flyover Complex
Ring Road
Opp. Moolchand Medicty, Defence Colony
New Delhi
Delhi 110024

+91 (0)11 4678 0080

http://www.lebistroduparc.com

Menu: around 1,800 INR

content.title: Nizamuddin Dargah, the origins of Indian Sufism

introduction.small: A ‘dargah' is a Sufi shrine housing the tomb of a figure revered for his piety. Here lies a key figure of Indian Sufism: Master Nizamuddin Auliya.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nizamuddin Dargah, the origins of Indian Sufism

paragraphs.text:
Sufism is an ascetic and mystical current of Islam. It is considered by most devotees to be the antidote to stereotyped Islam. Everyday, thousands of Muslims, Hindus, and Christians visit this mausoleum, which houses the master of Indian Sufism, Nizamuddin Auliya.

In this complex also lay the famous poet Amir Khusro and the eldest daughter of Mughal emperor Shah Jahan, Jahan Ara Begum. In the 17th century, the princess created the famous Chandni Chowk bazaar in Old Delhi, and a few public gardens. Near the mausoleum is a small mosque and, all around, you can wander through the labyrinth of narrow streets filled with stalls selling religious items.

Every Thursday and Sunday during Qawwalis, the sanctuary is adorned with lights and resonates with sounds of music, prayers and songs; the marble courtyard of the immaculate "dargah" becomes a sublime setting, worthy of the best Bollywood movies.

Nizamuddin Dargah‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬
Mathura Rd
Old Nizamuddin Bazaar
New Delhi
Delhi 110013

+91 (0)98 1177 8607

https://nizamuddinaulia.org

content.title: Fabindia, Anokhi, Kashmir Loom: the feel of India

introduction.small: Three stores for the lovers of textiles, fabrics, and garments sensitive to the art of touch. Weaving materials is an ancient craft, and an integral part of India's history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fabindia, Anokhi, Kashmir Loom: the feel of India

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 1960 by an American, John Bissell, Fabindia has created work opportunities for more than 15,000 villages in rural India by supporting artisans and valuing handmade items.

Today, it is a very popular chain of traditional clothing, home products, and accessories for travellers who love to stock up. Anokhi has specialised in block prints for more than 40 years. The brand has perfected this printing technique of wood engraving with wooden stamps carved in the desired pattern, which workers use to print ornamental designs on cotton, silk, or wool. You can buy a kurta (tunic), dhoti (pants), tablecloths, cushions, and bedspreads. In Jaipur, there is even an Anokhi museum at Amber Fort, which traces the company's history.

Finish the tour at Kashmir Loom, the temple of changra goats' hair (changra means Kashmir goats). This is the place to wrap yourself in the soft and voluptuous cashmere sweaters, stoles, and scarves.

Fabindia
62, Janpath Road

content.title: Hauz Khas: a walk in a bohemian neighbourhood

introduction.small: In Hauz Khas in the south of the city, antique dealers, artists, designers, and restaurants loudly sing La Bohème.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hauz Khas: a walk in a bohemian neighbourhood

paragraphs.text:
Until the 1980s, Hauz Khas was a village in the middle of residential neighbourhoods. Then fashion designers, artists, and architects discovered it, turning it into an ethno-chic enclave.

Start your day with a coffee or a chai (Indian tea with cardamom and milk) and a fortifying breakfast at Social. In the morning, walk along the streets of Deer Park. Then, especially if you love Indian cinema, stop at the All Arts shop, which sells movie posters and stills. Take a lunch break at OTB (Out of The Box) terrace cafe where mezzes revive your palate. Do not forget to make a detour to Nappa Dori for accessories and items dedicated to chic globetrotters. Check out Love Birds store, which is close by and known for its vintage fashion. As for Ogaan, their creed is contemporary Indian fashion. End your tour with a romantic trip to Café Bohemia, the most glamorous rooftop in Hauz Khas village, where music concerts and fusion cuisine will delight you.

content.title: Lodhi Gardens, The Garden of Five Senses… and others

introduction.small: Although Delhi is considered one of the most polluted cities in the world, the capital has some parks and gardens for fresh air.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lodhi Gardens, The Garden of Five Senses… and others

paragraphs.text:
The Lodhi Gardens were built by the Sunni dynasty of the same name in the 15th century.

This park covers nearly 36 hectares and contains the tombs, or rauza, of influential sultans, including those of Mohammed Shah and Sikandar Lodi. Octagonal, domed, and surrounded by several kiosks with cupolas, the tomb of Sultan Mohamed Shah is unique in Indo-Muslim architecture. In the south of the city, albeit a bit further out, is the Garden of Five Senses, which contains various floral installations on the theme of awakening sensations. It will surprise you with its tranquillity and serenity. You traverse a Mughal-style garden, a vegetal rainbow, a bamboo courtyard, a garden of stones...

Finally, head towards gigantic Deer Park where a bucolic stroll awaits you in bohemian Hauz Khas village. You may come across deer, monkeys, parrots, and rabbits.

Lodhi Gardens
Lodi Estate
New Delhi
Delhi 110003
+91 (0)11 2464 0079

Garden of Five Senses

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Delhi
content.introduction: Delhi has a humid, subtropical climate. The hot season begins in April and ends with the arrival of the monsoon in June, which brings intense humidity and more rainfall. Winters are usually mild.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in the Republic of India is the Indian Rupee (INR).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Indira-Gandhi International Airport
airports.description:
The Indira-Gandhi International Airport is located about 23 kilometres (14 miles) west of the city centre.
  • Four terminals
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 3 (Air France)
    • Hajj Terminal
    • Cargo Terminal

Getting from the airport to Delhi and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the Delhi-Gurgaon Expressway.
    • Parking facilities are available at each terminal. Prices start at INR 100 for 30 minutes and up to INR 500 per day.
    • Several car rental companies have counters outside the customs hall. An international driver's licence is required to rent a vehicle.
  • By rail
    The Airport Express Line of the Delhi Metro connects the airport with the city centre, with trains running daily every 25 minutes from 4.45 a.m. to 11.30 p.m. and a travel time of about 20 minutes. Fares are INR 10 to 60.
  • By bus
    Shuttle bus services connecting the airport with central parts of the city run every 15 minutes, 24/7. Travel times are between 30 and 45 minutes and the fare is INR 100 each way.
  • By taxi Taxis should be booked at the yellow prepaid taxi booths in the arrivals hall and cost around INR 400 for the trip to the city centre, which takes about 30 minutes.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +91 (0)124 337 6000 / +91 (0)124 4797 3000
  • Website: www.newdelhiairport.in

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Delhi
transportation.description: Delhi is a hectic city with very dense, and even chaotic, traffic at all hours of the day and night. At the outset, getting around the city may seem complicated. In fact, Delhi has a public transport system that is both reliable and efficient.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Delhi, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organize your stay.

information.title: Government of India Tourist Office in Delhi
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: 88, Janpath, Connaught Place, New Delhi
  • Telephone: +91 (0)11 2332 0008
  • Website: https://www.delhitourism.com

information.title: India travel guide
information.description:
The official travel website maintained by India's Ministry of Tourism provides a wealth of information on Delhi.

Website: www.incredibleindia.org

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is recommended that you obtain insurance covering health care expenses as well as medical evacuation or repatriation before you leave home. Delhi counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to India. However, booster doses of the following vaccines are strongly recommended for anyone travelling to the Indian subcontinent: diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio, typhoid, and hepatitis A and B. For longer stays, a rabies vaccination is also recommended.

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Water
information.description: It is recommended to drink bottled water.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Hindi phrases that will make your stay in Delhi a little easier:
phrases: What time is it ?: Time kya hai ?
I'm looking for (…): Mein janna naa chahta hoon
Where can I buy (…)?: Kahan khareed saktey hain (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Delhi
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Delhi each year.
The main ones are listed below:

events.title: January 26 : Republic Day (national)
events.description: Each year, the founding of the Republic of India on this day in 1950 is marked with pomp and pageantry. Celebrations include official ceremonies, a large and colourful military parade down Rajpath and general merry-making, including street theatre and fireworks.

events.title: February 12: Vasant Panchami (national)
events.description: This one-day Hindu festival celebrates the arrival of spring. In and around Delhi, the day is celebrated with kite flying, singing, dancing and feasting.

events.title: August 15 : Independence Day (national)
events.description: The anniversary of India's independence in 1947 is celebrated each year with flag raising and other patriotic ceremonies, military parades and cultural events.

events.title: September 17: Ganesh Chaturthi (national)
events.description: This festival is dedicated to Ganesh, the elephant-headed Hindu god of wisdom and prosperity. For three days, a huge procession, including many dancers and musicians, makes its way to the Chowpatty River carrying clay images and giant statues of the god, which are immersed in the water.

events.title: October 2: Gandhi Jayanti - Mahatma Gandhi's Birthday (national)
events.description: Commemorated throughout the country, this holiday celebrates the anniversary of Gandhi's birth on this day in 1869. All schools and stores are closed. Numerous religious ceremonies are held to remember independent India's founding father.

events.title: November: Diwali (national)
events.description: Oil lamps, lanterns and candles illuminate Delhi and all of India during this five-day festival of lights. According to tradition, Diwali celebrates the god Rama's return from 14 years of exile in the forest, when citizens lit his way with oil lamps, after his victory over the demon Ravana. Festivities also include feasting with loved ones, and exchanges of sweets and gifts.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for India
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you must apply for a visa before travelling to India. Visa extensions are not possible once you have arrived in the country, whether for tourism, studies or business. You should also note that, depending on the type of visa you require, the expiration date of your passport will need to be at least three to six months later than that of your visa.

Since Mai 2015, the e-Tourist Visa allowing for visa on arrival issuance has been available in 16 airports including in Delhi. It may be required for short-stays (less than 30 days).

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Delhi and India, be sure to check with the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs website: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/india/

usefulAddresses.title: Indian Embassy in France
usefulAddresses.description:

  • Website: www.ambinde.fr

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government offices
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. to 5 p.m.

banks.title: Banks
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 10 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: There is no daylight savings time in India
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
There are no hard-and-fast rules on tipping in India. Nevertheless, with the influx of tourists it has become increasingly common, especially in large cities like Delhi. The expected tip is usually about 10% of the bill. Some Delhi restaurants add a service charge to the bill. When this is the case, no additional tip is necessary. .
